image.altText: A young woman wearing a purple dress and a necklace smiles as she sits at a pub table with some food

items.synopsis: The body of Lilie James was found in the toilet area of the gym and a crime scene was established on the grounds. Investigating detectives are also searching for Ms James' colleague Paul Thijssen.

title.children: Prestigious Sydney school a crime scene after staff member found dead in suspected murder

image.altText: Ambulances ramped at the Royal Hobart Hospital

items.synopsis: A parliamentary inquiry into ambulance ramping in Tasmania receives "devastating" submissions, including stories of patients dying in corridors while separated from loved ones, but Premier Jeremy Rockliff says the problems are "not unique" to Tasmania — which he says is "doing well under the circumstances".

title.children: Suicide-risk patient ramped at hospital for so long that mental health order expired, inquiry hears

image.altText: A woman blurred in the background with a plant in the foreground

items.synopsis: Chelsea lived in "constant fear" of aggravating her father and says her childhood could have been different had she not been made to live with him. Now, changes in Australian law mean other children will hopefully be spared from the ordeal she endured.

title.children: The presumption of both parents having an equal say over their children in custody battles has been abolished

image.altText: A courtyard of a hospital showing burned out cars and fire damage.

items.synopsis: A week on it is still unclear who caused the blast at the al-Ahli Arab hospital in Gaza, but more Western leaders and governments have sought to blame a Palestinian rocket for the explosion which killed many civilians.

title.children: New assessments point to rocket failure in Gaza hospital blast, but questions remain

image.altText: Police cars and other vehicles are seen parked and travelling along a street in Lewiston, Maine at night

items.synopsis: Police in the north-east US city of Lewiston say locals should shelter as they search for an active shooter.

title.children: Police hunt for shooter on the run in Maine

image.altText: A man and person with a blurred face next to hanging horse carcasses.

items.synopsis: For years, Tasmania's top-ranked greyhound trainer was on the RSPCA's radar, but inspectors could find no wrongdoing despite monthly visits to his facility. In the end, what brought him down was not how he treated his dogs, because he did so inside the law.

title.children: This greyhound trainer has lost his licence — but it wasn't because he broke animal welfare laws

image.altText: A line drawing of a block of flats with curved surfaces, and a black and white portrait of an older man.

items.synopsis: Esmond Dorney is widely celebrated for his groundbreaking modernist buildings in Tasmania and Melbourne, but about 100 of his designs are missing.

title.children: Hunt for pioneering modernist architect's legacy after records destroyed. Could you be living in one of his homes?

image.altText: A male police officer speaks to a young girl in the arms of another male police officer

items.synopsis: He was one of the high-profile police officers who rescued Cleo Smith from her kidnapper, but now Cameron Blaine is at the centre of a Corruption and Crime Commission probe.

title.children: 'Unwise' relationship saw Cleo Smith detective leak confidential information to journalist, CCC report finds

image.altText: A power pole falls over during a fire

items.synopsis: Authorities have confirmed at least 16 homes have been destroyed in Tara, with dry lightning storms also causing havoc in the region for firefighters overnight.

title.children: Two dead, 16 homes lost in Tara as Queensland bushfire emergency continues

image.altText: Ms Mann smiles as she walks down a pier, the ocean in the background.

items.synopsis: A fresh investigation finds there were several failures in communication, staffing and the application of protocols before Monika Mann was discharged from Fiona Stanley Hospital in Perth, days after giving birth to twins.

title.children: Monika took her beautiful twins home from hospital. She was dead 12 hours later

image.altText: Tony Burke speaks at a press conference at Parliament House.

items.synopsis: The government department responsible for overseeing federal workplace and employment conditions had to pay $200,000 to rectify a more than $60,000 underpayment of 99 staff.

title.children: Staff underpaid at federal department responsible for employment

image.altText: An elderly woman in a church

items.synopsis: Clare Nowland, 95, died in hospital a week after she was tasered at an aged care home at Cooma in the state's south on May 17.

title.children: Family of Clare Nowland granted access to police body-worn footage of her tasering in aged care home

image.altText: Jodie Haydon, Anthony Albanese, Joe Biden and Jill Biden wave from the White House balcony.

items.synopsis: To say Anthony Albanese is walking a diplomatic tightrope as he mends fences with China, while drawing ever closer to the US, is putting it mildly, writes David Speers.

title.children: Just days before his China visit, Albanese is warmly welcomed to Washington — and there's no mistaking Biden's message

image.altText: Anthony Albanese and Joe Biden, seated on chairs, shake hands in the Oval Office.

items.synopsis: US President Joe Biden cautions Prime Minister Anthony Albanese against putting too much trust in China, as war and global instability overshadow talks at the White House.

title.children: Biden warns against fully trusting China as global tensions overshadow Albanese's White House visit

image.altText: A woman in black clothing on her balcony looking at a park, next to a pink stroller with a toy baby in it.

items.synopsis: Lenah arrived at a local park, expecting to meet with a child protection worker she thought would help find her family accommodation, but instead she found police and departmental officials lining the street.

title.children: 'Please, mum, we'll be good': When child protection took Lenah's children, they blamed themselves

image.altText: A row of men, dressed in combat gear, holding machine guns

items.synopsis: After Hamas launched its deadly assault on Israel, it seemed inevitable that a ground invasion would soon follow. But there are three big reasons why the military is not yet ready to enter the enclave.

title.children: 'You cannot wait indefinitely': Israel has three big reasons why it hasn't invaded Gaza … yet

image.altText: A group of men carry a body in a bag down a street

items.synopsis: An estimated 756 Palestinians have died in Israeli strikes in the past 24 hours, the Hamas-run Gaza health ministry says. Here are the latest Israel-Gaza updates.

title.children: Palestinian deaths estimated at over 6,000 with UN shelters overflowing, PM announces $15 million in aid for Gaza

image.altText: Two loafs of gluten free sour dough.

items.synopsis: Coeliac disease may be under diagnosed in one in seven kids like Isabel who have a close relative with the inflammatory gut condition. Here's what to look for and when to get tested.

title.children: 'My gran was sick for her whole adult life': Why entire families should be screened for coeliac disease

image.altText: A young girl holding a poster saying 'Remembering Cassius".

items.synopsis: Prosecutors are considering laying a new charge against one of the four people accused of murdering Perth schoolboy Cassius Turvey, the WA Supreme Court is told.

title.children: One of Cassius Turvey's accused murderers may face fresh charge amid 'new evidence', court hears

image.altText: Two side by side photos. One shows a partially bald man with red hair and green eyes. The second photo shows him walking away.

items.synopsis: Police and SES are scouring Townsville suburbs for missing man Paul McNab, who has not been seen for two days.

title.children: Helicopter launched in desperate search for missing north Queensland man

image.altText: RBA assistant governor Luci Ellis at a House of  Representatives economic committee hearing in Melbourne

items.synopsis: Bets on an interest rate rise next month gyrate dramatically on Senate testimony from the Reserve Bank governor, having surged yesterday on higher-than-expected inflation numbers.

title.children: Luci Ellis was an RBA assistant governor until earlier this month. She thinks it will raise rates next month

image.altText: A Commonwealth Bank branch in Melbourne's CBD

items.synopsis: RBA governor Michele Bullock tells Senate estimates that while slowing, annual rental prices are expected to reach 10 per cent in the coming months, the big four banks say another rate hike is imminent, and the ASX is lower. Follow live.

title.children: All big four banks predict November rate hike, ASX down

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Have you seen this story on the ABC NEWS website today? I've copied it below for you, but the nuts and bolts of it are this: The Department of Employment and Workplace Relations, the very department responsible for overseeing federal workplace and employment conditions, underpaid 99 staff. The department underpaid staff between July 2022 and August this year The department became aware of the prospect of the underpayment in June this year Staff received their reimbursement this week Read the full story here. (PS - ABC also has a history of underpaying staff)
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: When life imitates art: workplace govt dpt underpays staff

featuredLink.title: Staff underpaid at federal department responsible for employment

children.content: Have you seen this story on the ABC NEWS website today?
I've copied it below for you, but the nuts and bolts of it are this:
The Department of Employment and Workplace Relations, the very department responsible for overseeing federal workplace and employment conditions, underpaid 99 staff.
The department underpaid staff between July 2022 and August this year
The department became aware of the prospect of the underpayment in June this year
Staff received their reimbursement this week
Read the full story here.
(PS - ABC also has a history of underpaying staff)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: According to a poll by Refinitive, that would be 'no'. The central bank meets on December 31-November 1. The poll has a 98.4 per cent chance the bank will hold. (FYI the same source has a 57.3 per cent chance the Reserve Bank of Australia will pause - that number has been moving around quite a bit in the past two days) But back to the US. The research team and ANZ bank have sent through a note saying they expect the rate will remain on hold, but the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) will maintain its tightening bias. The team at ANZ think the sharp rise in bond yields reduces the need for further central bank tightening. As we all know, the rate hikes are to bring inflation down. In the US it's currently 3.7 per cent. That's still above it's target. Economists around the globe will be watching closely what the US central bank does, as well as the commentary from Chairman Jerome Powell at the conclusion of the meeting... because as the saying goes, when the US sneezes... we catch a cold.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: So will the US Fed lift its rate next week?

children.content: According to a poll by Refinitive, that would be 'no'.
The central bank meets on December 31-November 1.
The poll has a 98.4 per cent chance the bank will hold.
(FYI the same source has a 57.3 per cent chance the Reserve Bank of Australia will pause - that number has been moving around quite a bit in the past two days)
But back to the US.
The research team and ANZ bank have sent through a note saying they expect the rate will remain on hold, but the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) will maintain its tightening bias.
The team at ANZ think
the sharp rise in bond yields reduces the need for further central bank tightening
As we all know, the rate hikes are to bring
inflation
down. In the US it's
currently 3.7 per cent
. That's still above it's target.
Economists around the globe will be watching closely what the US central bank does, as well as the
commentary from Chairman Jerome Powell
at the conclusion of the meeting... because as the saying goes, when the US sneezes... we catch a cold.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Did you see Dan's post earlier about the ASX now at a 12-month low? Scroll down if you missed it. It turns out, it's not just us. That pesky 'higher for longer' catchphrase about interest rates is really dragging us all down - metaphorically/ emotionally/ psyhcologiacally/ financially - take your pick! US Treasury yields (take a look at the snapshot pinned above we're now keeping a closer eye on them here on the blog) are higher on fears the US Federal Reserve will hike its interest rate next week. That's limiting some of the risk taking in financial markets. "There is no anchor in US treasuries," said Ben Luk, Senior Multi Asset Strategist at State Street Global Markets. "If (the 10-year yield) doesn't stay below 5%, then I think it's still going to be a very choppy market for both US and Asia." Hong Kong's Hang Seng, Japan's Nikkei, China's SSE Index, South Korea's KOSPI and New Zealand's S & P 50 are all lower in today's trading session.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Asian stocks slide to 11-month lows

children.content: Did you see Dan's post earlier about the ASX now at a 12-month low? Scroll down if you missed it.
It turns out, it's not just us.
That pesky 'higher for longer' catchphrase about interest rates is really dragging us all down - metaphorically/ emotionally/ psyhcologiacally/ financially - take your pick!
US Treasury yields (take a look at the snapshot pinned above we're now keeping a closer eye on them here on the blog) are higher on fears the US Federal Reserve will hike its interest rate next week.
That's limiting some of the risk taking in financial markets.
"There is no anchor in US treasuries," said Ben Luk, Senior Multi Asset Strategist at State Street Global Markets.
"If (the 10-year yield) doesn't stay below 5%, then I think it's still going to be a very choppy market for both US and Asia."
Hong Kong's Hang Seng, Japan's Nikkei, China's SSE Index, South Korea's KOSPI and New Zealand's S
P 50 are all lower in today's trading session.

image.altText: Toyah Cordingley, 24, whose body was found at Wangetti Beach in far north Queensland October 22, 2018.

items.synopsis: Police have taken 500 witness statements in their case against a man they allege murdered Toyah Cordingley at a beach north of Cairns, a court has heard.

title.children: Toyah Cordingley's accused killer set to face trial in Cairns as defence lawyer seeks DNA evidence

image.altText: A woman looks at the camera with a look of sadness.

items.synopsis: Nadene Dodd, the mother of Cleveland Dodd — the first teenager to die in WA's youth detention system since records began — speaks for the first time since he took his own life, saying authorities "never helped him".

title.children: Nadene Dodd didn't know her son was in Unit 18 until she got a devastating call. She says he was failed by authorities

image.altText: First Nations man wearing close the gap shirt stands in river, in front of huge tree roots on a riverbank

items.synopsis: The Murray Lower Darling Rivers Indigenous Nations group launch a legal challenge against the NSW and federal governments, alleging consultation on the state's Fractured Rock Water Resource Plan was not properly conducted.

title.children: First Nations take legal action over 'inadequate' Murray-Darling water plan consultation

image.altText: Nicholas walks along outside in a white button-up shirt.

items.synopsis: Nicholas Reed, who was found guilty of setting the doors of Old Parliament House on fire, concedes in the ACT Supreme Court his actions "served no purpose".

title.children: Man who set fire to Old Parliament House apologises to local Indigenous groups for harm caused

image.altText: Daniel and Andrea Clifford on the left and the inside of the home showing cracks and taped off on the right

items.synopsis: A Victorian couple are homeless after after an earthquake caused "extensive" damage, leaving their house at risk of collapse.

title.children: Couple's home condemned after being rocked by earthquake

image.altText: ACT coat of arms on Magistrates Court building

items.synopsis: A year after jury misconduct terminated a high-profile rape trial in Canberra, the ACT government is set to introduce penalties of up to two years in jail for jurors who do the wrong thing.

title.children: Jury misconduct ended a recent high-profile trial in Canberra. Under new rules, that juror could have faced jail time

image.altText: Chelsea Gubecka clenches her fist

items.synopsis: Australia's first confirmed athlete for the Paris 2024 Olympic Games has been named, with open water swimmer Chelsea Gubecka thrilled to be heading to her second Olympics, even as questions remain over the event's River Seine location.

title.children: Open water swimmer named as Australia's first 2024 Olympian as River Seine remains a concern over pollution levels

image.altText: Penny Wong holding her hand up to her mouth pensively during a senate hearing.

items.synopsis: Foreign affairs officials say they have "every indication" that Australians in Lebanon are not listening to their advice to consider leaving the country, despite growing fears that the Israel-Gaza conflict could explode into a broader regional war.

title.children: Concerns Australians not heeding DFAT warnings to consider leaving Lebanon as Israel-Gaza war intensifies

image.altText: Three Indigenous women stand side by side looking into the distance with water behind them.

items.synopsis: As stone artefacts are pulled from waters around Australia, concerns are growing that "tens of thousands" of possible sites of archaeological significance are not being adequately protected. The latest concern is in the Top End, where a gas company is pushing ahead with a pipeline.

title.children: These Tiwi elders believe burial grounds are under threat from a gas pipeline. The company says they don't exist

image.altText: Two federal police officers are shown from behind at a Changjiang Currency Exchange outlet.

items.synopsis: Australian Federal Police arrest seven people in Melbourne and seize $50 million worth of luxury cars and property as part of a long-running investigation into an alleged money-laundering syndicate it says was operating "in plain sight".

title.children: Money laundering is usually done in the shadows. The AFP alleges this syndicate was operating in plain sight

image.altText: Donald Trump sits at a desk in court, wearing a blue suit and tie and looking unsatisfied.

items.synopsis: The former president violates a gag order in his civil fraud trial for the second time and is fined $US10,000 ($15,889).

title.children: Donald Trump fined for comments made outside New York fraud trial

image.altText: Glenn Maxwell roars with celebration after scoring a century

items.synopsis: All-rounder Glenn Maxwell produces the fastest 100 in the history of the World Cup, helping to propel Australia to the tournament's biggest-ever victory as Dutch bowler Bas de Leede concedes the most runs by a bowler in ODI history.

title.children: Glenn Maxwell's magnificent hundred helps brutalise the Netherlands at Cricket World Cup

image.altText: Adam and Damian, the creators of Odd Studio, stand with a huge wolf costume in their studio.

items.synopsis: In a workshop in Marrickville, this Australian team has worked on creating the monsters and practical effects on films including Star Wars, Alien and Mad Max. Their latest challenge is a pregnant werewolf.

title.children: 'Pinch-myself moment': Meet the Aussies who made the Darth Vader suit and your favourite monsters
